channel.title: [Java] Creating an XML list?
channel.description:
So I want to write an XML list for about 100-200 Music files.
No one wants to do that crap manually. :P
So how could I write a java file to output the following into a text/xml document: The Name of the song (taken from the "Title" Attribute you can put on sound files). The Artist of the song (taken from the "artist" attribute you can put on sound files). It's location based off the .class files current directory. (What I mean is if there is a sound file nested in src/music/library/sound.mp3 and the class file is nested in src/music/ it would print /library/sound.mp3)

item.title: [Java] Creating an XML list?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

HcoJustin:

It may be an ID3v2 tag, you’ll want to account for both

That must have been it, because it fixed the error ^.^

But now I’m getting this:

Exception in thread "main" org.blinkenlights.jid3.ID3Exception: Error reading ÿÿÔd v2 frame.
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.v2.ID3V2Frame.read(ID3V2Frame.java:492)
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.v2.ID3V2Frame.read(ID3V2Frame.java:218)
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.v2.ID3V2_3_0Tag.internalRead(ID3V2_3_0Tag.java:233)
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.v2.ID3V2Tag.read(ID3V2Tag.java:146)
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.MP3File.getID3V2Tag(MP3File.java:446)
	at id3Test.scan(id3Test.java:30)
	at id3Test.scan(id3Test.java:20)
	at id3Test.scan(id3Test.java:20)
	at id3Test.scan(id3Test.java:20)
	at id3Test.main(id3Test.java:13)
Caused by: java.lang.NegativeArraySizeException
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.v2.ID3V2Frame.read(ID3V2Frame.java:321)
	... 9 more

I can’t exactly understand why I’m getting it, because it’s not the files

Edit:
I temporary removed the files that were causing it (My AFI music >.>)
and It’s up to like 4k of my files.

Edit 2:
So apparently there was something wrong with my AFI songs’ ID3 tags.
As it went through the rest of them just fine

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Creating an XML list?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

HcoJustin:

You don’t need an array…

			        ID3Tag[] aoID3Tag = oMediaFile.getTags();
			        for (int i=0; i < aoID3Tag.length; i++)
			        {
			            if (aoID3Tag[i] instanceof ID3V1_0Tag)
			            {
			                ID3V1_0Tag oID3V1_0Tag = (ID3V1_0Tag)aoID3Tag[i];
	
			                if (oID3V1_0Tag.getTitle() != null)
			                {
			                	try {
			    					bw = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("playlist.xml", true));
			    					bw.write("<SONG URL=\""+str+"\" TITLE=\""+oID3V1_0Tag.getTitle()+ "\" ARTIST=\""+
			    					 oID3V1_0Tag.getArtist() + "\" />\n"); 
			    					bw.flush();
			    					bw.close();
			    				}
			    				catch (IOException ioe2) {}
			    				}
			                    System.out.println("Title = " + oID3V1_0Tag.getTitle());
			                    System.out.println("ContArt = " + oID3V1_0Tag.getArtist());
			                }
			            }

I use the array there for the for loop and to check if the music file is an instance of the ID3 tag.
The second part, doesn’t need an array. But what do I do about the first part. The array in the for loop

item.title: [Java] Creating an XML list?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

HcoJustin:

The file has an invalid ID3v2 frame. Because you using getTags, it has to decode ALL of them. You’ll want to use getID3V1Tag to get the single tag instead. ID3v1 contains everything you need for your list

If I use getID3V1Tag my array won’t work properly.
What other ID3 tag ones work with an array, but doesn’t need to run through all the codes.
Or is there a way I can add in an exception, to check if something is missing, to just skip over?

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Creating an XML list?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

The file has an invalid ID3v2 frame. Because you using getTags, it has to decode ALL of them. You’ll want to use getID3V1Tag to get the single tag instead. ID3v1 contains everything you need for your list

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Creating an XML list?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Thanks everyone for the help.

I know my code isn’t efficient, or neat at all. But I got it done:

import java.io.*;

import org.blinkenlights.jid3.*;
import org.blinkenlights.jid3.v1.*;
//import org.blinkenlights.jid3.v2.*;

public class id3Test
{
	static String str = "";
	public static void main(String[] args) throws ID3Exception
    {
		File path = new File("./");
		scan(path);
    }
	public static void scan(File file) throws ID3Exception
	{
		BufferedWriter bw = null;
		for (File f : file.listFiles()){
			if (f.isDirectory())
				scan(f);
			else{
			str = ""+f;
			if(str.contains("mp3")){
				/****/
			        File oSourceFile = new File(str);
	
			        MediaFile oMediaFile = new MP3File(oSourceFile);
	
			        ID3Tag[] aoID3Tag = oMediaFile.getTags();
			        for (int i=0; i < aoID3Tag.length; i++)
			        {
			            if (aoID3Tag[i] instanceof ID3V1_0Tag)
			            {
			                ID3V1_0Tag oID3V1_0Tag = (ID3V1_0Tag)aoID3Tag[i];
	
			                if (oID3V1_0Tag.getTitle() != null)
			                {
			                	try {
			    					bw = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("playlist.xml", true));
			    					bw.write("<SONG URL=\""+str+"\" TITLE=\""+oID3V1_0Tag.getTitle()+ "\" ARTIST=\""+
			    					 oID3V1_0Tag.getArtist() + "\" />\n"); 
			    					bw.flush();
			    					bw.close();
			    				}
			    				catch (IOException ioe2) {}
			    				}
			                    System.out.println("Title = " + oID3V1_0Tag.getTitle());
			                    System.out.println("ContArt = " + oID3V1_0Tag.getArtist());
			                }
			                // etc.
			            }
			        }
				}
			}
		}
	}

The output:

<SONG URL=".\Music\10 Years\Division\Beautiful.mp3" TITLE="Beautiful" ARTIST="10 Years" />
<SONG URL=".\Music\10 Years\Division\Dying Youth.mp3" TITLE="Dying Youth" ARTIST="10 Years" />
<SONG URL=".\Music\10 Years\Division\Just Can't Win.mp3" TITLE="Just Can't Win" ARTIST="10 Years" />

About 170-200 songs into it I get this:

Exception in thread "main" org.blinkenlights.jid3.ID3Exception: Error reading ÿûÒd v2 frame.
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.v2.ID3V2Frame.read(ID3V2Frame.java:492)
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.v2.ID3V2Frame.read(ID3V2Frame.java:218)
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.v2.ID3V2_3_0Tag.internalRead(ID3V2_3_0Tag.java:233)
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.v2.ID3V2Tag.read(ID3V2Tag.java:146)
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.MP3File.getID3V2Tag(MP3File.java:446)
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.MP3File.getTags(MP3File.java:381)
	at id3Test.scan(id3Test.java:27)
	at id3Test.scan(id3Test.java:19)
	at id3Test.scan(id3Test.java:19)
	at id3Test.scan(id3Test.java:19)
	at id3Test.main(id3Test.java:12)
Caused by: java.io.EOFException
	at java.io.DataInputStream.readFully(Unknown Source)
	at java.io.DataInputStream.readFully(Unknown Source)
	at org.blinkenlights.jid3.v2.ID3V2Frame.read(ID3V2Frame.java:356)
	... 10 more

It’s something to do with the ID3 source I used. What could I do to fix this?

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Creating an XML list?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

private List<Mp3File> build(File root) throws Exception { List<Mp3File> files = new ArrayList<Mp3File>(); for(File f : root.listFiles()) { if(f.isDirectory() && recursive) { files.addAll(build(f)); } else if(f.getName().toLowerCase().endsWith(".mp3")) { files.add(new Mp3File(f.getAbsolutePath())); } } return files; }

and for the output

public String getOutput() { StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(); sb.append("<list>\n"); for(Mp3File file : files) { if(file.hasId3v1Tag()) { ID3v1 tag = file.getId3v1Tag(); sb.append(" <song url=\"" + file.getFilename() + "\" title=\"" + tag.getTitle() + "\" artist=\"" + tag.getArtist() + "\">\n"); } else { sb.append(" <song url=\"" + file.getFilename() + "\" title=\"" + new File(file.getFilename()).getName() + "\" artist=\"Unknown Artist\">\n"); } } sb.append("</list>"); return sb.toString(); }

<list> <song url="C:\Users\Justin\Music\Saints Row The Third - The Soundtrack\01 Saints Row The Third.mp3" title="Saints Row The Third" artist="Malcolm Kirby Jr."> <song url="C:\Users\Justin\Music\Saints Row The Third - The Soundtrack\02 When Good Heists Go Bad.mp3" title="When Good Heists Go Bad" artist="Malcolm Kirby Jr."> <song url="C:\Users\Justin\Music\Saints Row The Third - The Soundtrack\03 The Mission Part 1.mp3" title="The Mission Part 1" artist="Malcolm Kirby Jr."> <song url="C:\Users\Justin\Music\Saints Row The Third - The Soundtrack\04 The Mission Part 2.mp3" title="The Mission Part 2" artist="Malcolm Kirby Jr."> <song url="C:\Users\Justin\Music\Saints Row The Third - The Soundtrack\05 Oleg and Kinzie.mp3" title="Oleg and Kinzie" artist="Malcolm Kirby Jr."> <song url="C:\Users\Justin\Music\Saints Row The Third - The Soundtrack\06 Killbane and the Syndicate.mp3" title="Killbane and the Syndicate" artist="Malcolm Kirby Jr."> <song url="C:\Users\Justin\Music\Saints Row The Third - The Soundtrack\07 Stag.mp3" title="Stag" artist="Malcolm Kirby Jr."> <song url="C:\Users\Justin\Music\Saints Row The Third - The Soundtrack\08 End Game.mp3" title="End Game" artist="Malcolm Kirby Jr."> <song url="C:\Users\Justin\Music\zircon - Augment.mp3" title="zircon - Augment.mp3" artist="Unknown Artist"> </list>

item.title: [Java] Creating an XML list?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

So here’s what I got so far ^.^:

import java.io.*;
public class directoryTest
{
public static void main(String args[])throws IOException
	{
		File path = new File("./");
		BufferedWriter bw = null;
		
		File [] files = path.listFiles();
		for (int i = 0; i < files.length; i++){
			if (files[i].isFile()){
				try {
					bw = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("Library.xml", true));
					bw.write(""+files[i]+"\n"); 
					bw.flush();
				}
				catch (IOException ioe2) {}
			}
		}
		bw.close();
	}

}

and here’s what it prints:

.\compile.bat
.\directoryTest.class
.\directoryTest.java
.\run.bat

I need to get it to search the whole directory. I’ve got a folder with a sub-folder and a text doc in the same are.
So it looks like:

.\compile.bat .\directoryTest.class .\directoryTest.java .\run.bat .\directory1\anotherDir\textFile.txt
Yes, that is the directory to the text file. No I do not want to list the entire directory, as the idea is it could go through all sub directories of the folder(s) on it's own

Read full topic

item.description:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:31, topic:521229”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=639740.msg4313078#msg4313078 date=1371052463]

Thank you Roger, for actually helping.

That is just a simple recursion search… did you really not know how to do it?

I’ve never really branched outside of the rsps scene with java.
[/quote]

Not a problem. I learned how to parse data from the rsc scene about 6 years ago. You’re going to want to learn what the Java API has to offer and practice makes perfect. You should learn the basics of java online and practice until you have a good understanding before reading a book.

If you’re still needing help post your code that you’re stuck with. I only provided a starting point since spoon feeding does nothing.[/quote]
Yeah I’ve been trying to actually learn java and not just deal with rsps. But it takes time

If someone wants they can close this or what ever.
